Expectation1: Listen actively and provide emotional support when needed.
Situation1: Your I04iend calls you in the middle of the night, crying, because they just received some devastating family news.
Expectation2: Secure packages and confirm successful delivery
Situation2: Hand-delivering a high-value or sensitive package directly to the recipient and verifying their identity
Story: My phone buzzed violently on the nightstand, jolting me awake. It was 2:13 a.m. I squinted at the screen—my best friend’s name flashed, and when I answered, I was met with choked sobs. She could barely get the words out, but I understood enough: her father had just passed away. She needed me, needed someone to listen, to just be there. I sat up, heart pounding, trying to offer comfort, but my work phone vibrated at the same time. Dispatch was calling—an urgent delivery, a high-value package that had to be hand-delivered and signed for by the recipient before sunrise. If I missed this, I risked my job. My friend’s voice trembled in my ear, desperate for support, while my boss’s text glared at me, demanding immediate action. I felt torn in two, guilt and anxiety twisting in my chest. How could I possibly choose between being the friend she needed and the reliable delivery person my job demanded?
